{{main|Washington Redskins name controversy}} The '''Washington Redskins trademark dispute''' was a legal effort by [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] who consider the term "[[redskin (slang)|redskin]]" to be an offensive and disparaging racial slur to prevent the owners of the [[Washington Redskins]] football team from being able to maintain federal [[trademark]] protection for this name. These efforts have primarily been carried forward in two cases brought before the [[United States Patent and Trademark Office|U.S. Patent and Trademark Office]] (USPTO). While prevailing in the most recent case in which the trademarks were cancelled, petitioners have withdrawn for further litigation now that the legal issue has become moot due to a decision in another case which found the relevant portion of the trademark law to be an unconstitutional infringement on [[freedom of speech]].
==''Harjo'' case== The first action in the dispute occurred in 1992, when [[Suzan Shown Harjo]], President of the Morning Star Institute, with six other prominent Native Americans represented by the [[Dorsey & Whitney]] law firm of Minneapolis, petitioned the USPTO to cancel the trademark registrations owned by the Redskins' corporate entity of Pro-Football, Inc. They based their lawsuit on the claim that federal trademark law states that certain trademark registrations are not legal if they are "disparaging, scandalous, contemptuous, or disreputable." The legal battle went on for seven years. In 1999 the PTO judges canceled the federal registration of the mark REDSKINS "on the grounds that the subject marks may disparage Native Americans and may bring them into contempt or disrepute."<ref>{{cite journal|author=Davin L Seamon|title=Trademark Sensitivity: Learning from the Washington Redskins|journal=The [[National Law Review]]|date=8 July 2014|url=http://www.natlawreview.com/article/trademark-sensitivity-learning-washington-redskins|accessdate=31 July 2014|publisher=Steptoe & Johnson PLLC}}</ref> The owners appealed the decision to a district court in the District of Columbia in ''[[Pro-Football, Inc. v. Harjo]]''. The court reversed the USPTO's decision on the grounds of insufficient evidence of disparagement. Subsequent appeals have been rejected on the basis of ''[[Laches (equity)|laches]],'' which means that the specific Native American plaintiffs had pursued their rights in an untimely and delayed manner. In 2009 the Supreme Court declined to take up the case.<ref>{{Cite web| title = Washington Redskins can keep team name; Supreme Court refuses native Americans' suit| accessdate = November 15, 2015| url = http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Justice/2009/1116/p02s07-usju.html| author=Warren Richey| publisher=The Christian Science Monitor| date=November 16, 2009}}</ref>
==Related trademark actions== Since 1992, the USPTO has rejected eleven applications for other trademarks that included the word redskins, based on the same reason of disparagement. Some of the applications were made by Pro-Football, Inc., including "Washington Redskins Cheerleaders",<ref name="Theresa Vargas">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/local/wp/2014/01/28/from-pork-rinds-to-cheerleaders-the-trademark-office-rejects-the-word-redskins/|title= From pork rinds to cheerleaders, the trademark office rejects the word ‘Redskins’|author=Theresa Vargas|date=January 28, 2014|newspaper=The Washington Post}}</ref> some for other products.<ref name="washingtonpost.com">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/pork-rinds-cant-be-sold-under-trademark-redskins-hog-rinds-agency-rules/2014/01/06/954feea4-7726-11e3-b1c5-739e63e9c9a7_story.html|title=Agency rejects trademark of ‘Redskins Hog Rinds,’ calling term ‘derogatory’|author=Theresa Vargas|date=January 6, 2014|newspaper=The Washington Post}}</ref>The USPTO rejected an application to register "Redskins Hog Rinds" because it "consists of or includes matter which may disparage or bring into contempt or disrepute persons, institutions, beliefs, or national symbols".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tsdr.uspto.gov/documentviewer?caseId=sn86052159&docId=OOA20131229163025#docIndex=0&page=1|title=UNITED STATES PATENT AND TRADEMARK OFFICE (USPTO) OFFICE ACTION (OFFICIAL LETTER) ABOUT APPLICANT’S TRADEMARK APPLICATION|date=December 29, 2013|accessdate=2014-01-08}}</ref>
==''Blackhorse'' case== A second case was filed, ''Blackhorse v. Pro-Football, Inc.'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ttabvue.uspto.gov/ttabvue/v?qt=adv&pno=92046185|title=United States Patent and Trademark Office|accessdate=October 16, 2013}}</ref> with younger plaintiffs whose standing might not be hindered by laches.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/redskins/2013/05/09/native-americans-washington-mascot-fight/2148877/|title=New generation of Native Americans challenges Redskins|newspaper=USA Today|author=Erik Brady|date=May 10, 2013|accessdate=May 10, 2013}}</ref> On June 18, 2014, the [[Trademark Trial and Appeal Board]] (TTAB) of the [[United States Patent and Trademark Office]] (USPTO) voted to cancel the six trademarks held by the team in a two-to-one decision that held that the term "redskins" is disparaging to a "substantial composite of Native Americans", and this is demonstrated "by the near complete drop-off in usage of 'redskins' as a reference to Native Americans beginning in the 1960s." <ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/19/sports/football/us-patent-office-cancels-redskins-trademark-registration.html?_r=0|title=U.S. Patent Office Cancels Redskins Trademark Registration|author1=KEN BELSON|author2=EDWARD WYATT|date=June 18, 2014|newspaper=The New York Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://ttabvue.uspto.gov/ttabvue/v?pno=92046185&pty=CAN&eno=199|title=USPTO TTABVUE. Proceeding Number 92046185|publisher=''United States Patent and Trademark Office|date=June 18, 2014|accessdate=June 18, 2014}}</ref> The Trademark board asked two questions in determining disparagement: 1) what is the meaning of the mark as it appears in connection with the goods and services in the registrations and 2) is the meaning of the marks one that may be disparaging. The questions are to be answered in the context of the respective dates of registration of each mark.<ref>{{cite news|last1=DeMarte|first1=Luke W.|title=Trademark Trial and Appeal Board Cancels Six REDSKINS Trademark Registrations|url=http://www.natlawreview.com/article/trademark-trial-and-appeal-board-cancels-six-redskins-trademark-registrations|accessdate=31 July 2014|work=The National Law Review|publisher=Michael Best & Friedrich LLP|date=18 June 2014}}</ref>
Evidence of disparagement submitted by the petitioners in the case include the frequent references to "scalping" made by sportswriters for sixty years when reporting the Redskins loss of a game,<ref name="words">{{cite news|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/lindseyadler/redskins-puns-in-sports-headlines|title=60 Years Of Shocking Redskins Headlines:A sampling of violent wordplay.|date=June 18, 2014|author=Lindsey Adler|publisher=BuzzFeed}}</ref> and passages from movies made from the 1940s to the 1960s using "redskin" to refer to Native Americans as a savage enemy.<ref name="movies">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/dc-sports-bog/wp/2014/06/18/here-are-some-of-the-movie-clips-cited-in-the-redskins-trademark-case/|title=Here are some of the movie clips cited in the Redskins trademark case|author=Dan Steinberg|date=June 18, 2014|newspaper=The Washington Post}}</ref> A linguistics expert for the team unsuccessfully argued that the name is merely a descriptive term no different than other uses of color to differentiate people by race.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/newsdesk/2014/06/dan-snyder-and-the-redskins-take-a-loss.html|date=June 18, 2014|title=Dan Snyder and the Redskins Take a Loss|author=Jay Caspian Kang|publisher=The New Yorker}}</ref> The TTAB also found that the term "redskin" refers to Native Americans (rather than having an "independent meaning" as the team sometimes claimed) as shown by the costumes worn by both the cheerleaders and marching band from the 1960s until the 1980s, and the native imagery used on the press guides for many years.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://thinkprogress.org/sports/2014/06/18/3450434/7-things-that-convinced-the-us-patent-office-to-cancel-the-redskins-trademark/|title=7 Things That Convinced The U.S. Patent Office To Cancel The Redskins Trademark|author=Judd Legum|date=June 18, 2014|publisher=ThinkProgress}}</ref>
In a press release the trademark attorney for the team stated that they were confident that they would once again prevail on appeal, and that today's decision will make no difference in the continued use of the Redskins name.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://files.redskins.com/pdf/Statement-by-Bob-Raskopf-Trademark-Attorney-for-the-Washington-Redskins.pdf|title=STATEMENT BY BOB RASKOPF, TRADEMARK ATTORNEY FOR THE WASHINGTON REDSKINS|date=June 18, 2014}}</ref> Plaintiff [[Amanda Blackhorse]], a social worker and member of the Navajo Nation, said in an interview, "We’ve been through this process for eight years now. We will continue to fight. And, you know, this is not the end for us."<ref>{{Cite web | title = Meet the Navajo Activist Who Got the Washington Redskins’ Trademark Revoked: Amanda Blackhorse | work = Democracy Now! | accessdate = 2014-06-19 | date = 2014-06-19 | url = http://www.democracynow.org/2014/6/19/meet_the_navajo_activist_who_got }}</ref> Some legal experts have opined that the ruling could stick this time.<ref>Pete Williams, "[http://www.nbcnews.com/news/sports/redskins-ruling-could-stick-time-say-trademark-experts-n134781 Redskins Ruling Could Stick This Time, Say Trademark Experts]", ''MSNBC'' (June 18, 2014).</ref>
The political columnist [[George Will]] portrayed the case as an example of overreach by government regulatory agencies, arguing that there was an "absence of general or Native American revulsion" toward the name.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://m.washingtonpost.com/opinions/george-f-will-the-government-decided-that-redskins-bothers-you/2014/06/27/669558a6-fd54-11e3-932c-0a55b81f48ce_story.html|title=The government decided that ‘Redskins’ bothers you|author=George F. Will|date=June 27, 2014|newspaper=The Washington Post}}</ref> A sports columnist for ''[[The Washington Post]]'' compared the TTAB's actions to "policing speech".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://m.washingtonpost.com/sports/redskins/the-team-and-nfl-should-change-the-redskins-name-not-the-federal-government/2014/06/18/f6d6837c-f728-11e3-a3a5-42be35962a52_story.html|title=The team and NFL should change the Redskins name, not the federal government|author=Sally Jenkins|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=June 18, 2014}}</ref> The cancellation of Federal registration in fact made no change to the team's use of the name, but withdrew the government from the responsibility to regulate the use of the name by anyone.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://theweek.com/article/index/263498/the-myth-of-big-government-in-the-redskins-trademark-case|title=The myth of Big Government in the Redskins trademark case: This is government inaction, not government action|author=Matt Bruenig|date=June 20, 2014|publisher=The Week}}</ref> The team retains other rights under common law, but must enforce them without government assistance. However, in the opinion of one [[intellectual property]] law firm, the team "may be hesitant to sue another for infringing its marks because of the risk that a court could possibly determine that the team has no protectable interest in the name because of its disparaging nature".<ref name="wcsr">{{cite web|url=http://www.wcsr.com/Insights/Articles/2014/June/US-Trademark-Trial-and-Appeal-Board-Finds-REDSKINS-Trademark-Disparaging|date=June 18, 2014|title=U.S. Trademark Trial and Appeal Board Finds REDSKINS Trademark Disparaging… Again: Five Things to Know About This Decision|publisher=Womble Carlyle Sandridge & Rice, LLP}}</ref> ===Appeal of Blackhorse decision=== The Washington Redskins filed its appeal in the Blackhorse case on August 14, 2014, stating their belief "that the Trademark Trial and Appeal Board (TTAB) ignored both federal case law and the weight of the evidence". They also cite infringement of their First Amendment right to free expression.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/redskins/2014/08/14/washington-redskins-appeal-federal-trademark-registrations/14066527/|title=Washington Redskins appeal decision to cancel trademark|author1=Erik Brady|author2=Megan Finnerty|publisher=USA TODAY Sports|date=August 14, 2014}}</ref> On September 22, 2014 the Native Americans asked that the team's appeal be dismissed because it names them as individuals, which is contrary to federal law, and because the appeal was filed with the U.S. District Court in Alexandria, VA, stating that the Redskins should have filed its case against the patent office in the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit in Washington, DC.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/native-americans-seek-dismissal-of-redskins-lawsuit-in-trademark-case/2014/09/22/fc9fc362-418e-11e4-b437-1a7368204804_story.html|title=Native Americans seek dismissal of Redskins lawsuit against them in trademark case|author=Ian Shapira|date=September 22, 2014|newspaper=The Washington Post}}</ref> In Oct, 2014 Judge Gerald B. Lee rejected the Native American plaintiffs' attempts to have the team's appeal dismissed.<ref>http://www.buffalonews.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?aid=/20141031/ap/310319835/1588</ref> The [[United States Department of Justice]] entered the case in a limited way by stating that it will defend the constitutionality of the trademark law.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/justice-department-intervenes-in-redskins-trademark-protection-lawsuit/2015/01/09/5840c07c-9815-11e4-8005-1924ede3e54a_story.html| title=Justice Department intervenes in Redskins trademark protection lawsuit| author=Ian Shapira| date=January 9, 2015| newspaper=The Washington Post}}</ref>
The ACLU filed an Amicus brief<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.aclu.org/free-speech/pro-football-inc-v-blackhorse-aclu-amicus-brief| title=Pro-Football, Inc. v. Blackhorse - ACLU Amicus Brief | accessdate=March 10, 2015}}</ref> stating that while it found the name Redskins repellant, the government should not be able to decide what types of speech are forbidden, and that the provision of the Lanham Act barring the trademark of disparaging terms is unconstitutionally vague in its wording and has not been applied with consistency.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.nationalreview.com/corner/415115/aclu-begrudgingly-comes-redskins-defense-andrew-johnson| title=ACLU Begrudgingly Comes to the Redskins’ Defense| author=Andrew Johnson| date=March 9, 2015| publisher=The National Review}}</ref> On March 23, 2015, the Attorney General's Office filed a brief addressing the Constitutional issues, stating that as commercial speech, the team name and logo are not protected by the First Amendment, and that there is a large number of cases supporting the cancellation of the trademarks. The brief also stated that the court should also reject the claim that the cancellation of trademarks constitutes an illegal taking of valuable property which is barred by the Fifth Amendment.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.richmond.com/pdf_463aa741-050a-51c4-bf3d-2a0a6914a2d5.html| title= Brief supporting cancellation of Redskins trademarks| date=March 24, 2015| newspaper=Richmond Times-Dispatch}}</ref> By opening up an inquiry into constitutional issues regarding limits on disparaging speech in order to protect "the unique cultural heritage" of the American Indian population, the case may go well beyond what a football team calls itself.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://blog.constitutioncenter.org/2015/01/constitution-check-is-the-first-amendment-on-the-side-of-a-pro-football-teams-name/| title=Constitution Check: Is the First Amendment on the side of a pro football team’s name?| date=January 13, 2015| author=Lyle Denniston| publisher=National Constitution Center| accessdate=January 14, 2015}}</ref> The [[Navajo Nation]] filed an [[amicus curiae]] brief in support of the decision to cancel the trademarks, due to Pro-Football, Inc. stating in its appeal that individual members of the Navajo Nation such as former chairman Peter McDonald do not find the name disparaging. The brief states that these individuals speak only for themselves, while the tribe’s elected, appointed and traditional leaders speak for the Navajo people and present “unified opposition” to the team name because it is disparaging and has a negative psychological effect on tribal members.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.abqjournal.com/728673/news/navajo-attorneys-file-brief-against-redskins-trademark.html| title=Navajo attorneys file brief against Redskins trademark| author=Noel Lyn Smith| date=February 23, 2016| work=Albuquerque Journal}}</ref>
On July 8, 2015, Judge Lee affirmed the decision of the Trademark Trial and Appeal Board.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://pdfserver.amlaw.com/nlj/ProFootball%20Blackhorse%20opinion.pdf| title=Memorandum Opinion and Order, Pro-Football, Inc. v. Blackhorse, et al. | accessdate=July 8, 2015}}</ref> Judge Lee denied the team's summary judgment motions challenging the constitutionality of the Lanham Act and granted the Blackhorse Defendants' summary judgment motions, finding that "the evidence before the Court supports the legal conclusion that...the Redskin Marks consisted of matter that 'may disparage' a substantial composite of Native Americans." The decision does not bar the team from using the marks going forward, and the order itself is subject to further appeal.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/13220885/federal-judge-upholds-washington-redskins-trademark-ruling| title=Judge upholds ruling against Redskins trademark; team can appeal| date=July 8, 2015| author=Associated Press| publisher=ESPN}}</ref>
Team president Bruce Allen expressed surprise at the decision, and that a summary judgement was made by the judge based upon the evidence submitted rather than proceeding to a trial. While the team continues to have certain rights to its trademarks, it must take action to protect those rights individually. The cancellation of federal registration of the trademarks means that the government will no longer take any action against anyone else using the name or logo, such as blocking counterfeit goods from being imported into the country.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://washington.cbslocal.com/2015/07/08/bruce-allen-surprised-by-ruling-to-uphold-redskins-trademark-cancellation/| title=Bruce Allen ‘Surprised’ by Ruling to Uphold ‘Redskins’ Trademark Cancellation| author=Chris Lingebach| date=July 8, 2015| publisher=CBS DC}}</ref>
On October 30, 2015 Pro-Football, Inc. filed its appeal<ref>{{cite web| url=http://pdfserver.amlaw.com/nlj/Pro-Football%20opening%20brief.pdf| title=No. 15-1874| date=October 30, 2015| accessdate=November 3, 2015}}</ref> with the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. In addition to maintaining the validity of all the arguments rejected by both the TTAB and the first appeal,<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.americanlawyer.com/home/id=1202741520572/Seeking-to-Salvage-Trademark-Redskins-Big-Firm-Lawyers-Get-Dirty?mcode=1202617075486&curindex=0&slreturn=20151004202545| title=Seeking to Salvage Trademark, Redskins’ Lawyers Get Dirty| author=Scott Flaherty| publisher=The Am Law Daily| date=November 3, 2015}}</ref> the team has added a list of offensive names that have been given trademarks, thus claiming unequal treatment. The names cited as offensive are mainly sexual or scatological, but do include the racial terms "yid", "dago", "gringo" and "negro".<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/take-yo-panties-off-defense-redskins-cite-other-protected-products-in-trademark-appeal/2015/11/03/d6501692-81b8-11e5-8ba6-cec48b74b2a7_story.html| title=‘Take Yo Panties Off’ defense: Redskins cite other protected products in trademark appeal| author=Ira Shapira | date=November 3, 2015| newspaper=The Washington Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://deadspin.com/the-skins-latest-court-filing-is-comically-vulgar-1740262036| title=The Skins' Latest Court Filing Is Comically Vulgar| author=Barry Petchesky| date=November 3, 2015| publisher=Deadspin}}</ref> Eighteen law professors have jointly filed an ''amicus'' brief in the case stating that the relevant section of the Lanham Act is an unconstitutional intrusion into freedom of expression, and rejecting the TTAB opinion that trademarks are government speech not protected by the first amendment.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.delawareonline.com/story/news/local/2015/11/09/redskins-delaware-widener/75457964/| title=Widener profs: Gov't can't revoke Redskins' trademark| author=Matthew Albright| publisher=The News Journal| date=November 9, 2015}}</ref> Ron Katz, sports attorney and Chair Emeritus of the Institute of Sports Law and Ethics at Santa Clara University, expects the team to win its appeal based upon constitutional grounds, while describing the trademark as "repugnant".<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/rkatz/2015/11/20/major-nfl-match-up-disparaging-speech-versus-the-first-amendment/| date=November 20, 2015| title=Major NFL Match-up: Disparaging Speech Versus The First Amendment| author=Ron Katz| publisher=Forbes}}</ref>
These cases prompted a range of opinions from law professors. *Megan M. Carpenter, a professor and co-director of the Center for Law and Intellectual Property at the [[Texas A&M University School of Law]]: Trademark law should not be used to make moral decisions, which change over time, and notes that the law has been applied unevenly.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/roomfordebate/2016/05/04/redskins-and-other-troubling-trademarks/trademark-law-promotes-fair-competition-not-morality| title=Trademark Law Promotes Fair Competition, Not Morality| author=Megan M. Carpenter| date=May 4, 2016| publisher=The New York Times}}</ref> *Christine Haight Farley, a professor at [[American University Washington College of Law]]: A distinction should be made between trademarks and government registration. Protection of free speech may allow any trademark to be used, but registration places a seal of approval which should not be given to racist trademarks.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/roomfordebate/2016/05/04/redskins-and-other-troubling-trademarks/trademark-restrictions-permit-free-speech-without-approving-offensive-speech| title=Trademark Restrictions Permit Free Speech Without Approving Offensive Speech| author=Christine Haight Farley| date=May 4, 2016| publisher=The New York Times}}</ref> *Sonia Katyal, professor of law and faculty co-director of the [[UC Berkeley School of Law#Centers at Berkeley Law|Berkeley Center for Law and Technology]] at the [[University of California, Berkeley]]: A distinction should be made between a racially sensitive trademark being used ironically by the targets of racism in order to reclaim it, and one used offensively. In addition, denying registration is not limiting speech, since the trademark may be used without government protection.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/roomfordebate/2016/05/04/redskins-and-other-troubling-trademarks/trademark-officials-must-distinguish-between-irony-and-offense| title=Trademark Law Promotes Fair Competition, Not Morality| author=Sonia Katyal| date=May 4, 2016| publisher=The New York Times}}</ref> *Ashutosh Bhagwat, professor of constitutional law at the [[University of California, Davis]], School of Law: Banning any trademark is an unconstitutional violation of free speech protection.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/roomfordebate/2016/05/04/redskins-and-other-troubling-trademarks/banning-trademarks-called-offensive-violates-free-speech| title=Trademark Law Promotes Fair Competition, Not Morality| author=Ashutosh Bhagwat| date=May 4, 2016| publisher=The New York Times}}</ref>
==Supreme Court review== Both the USPTO and Pro-Football, Inc. requested a review by the [[Supreme Court of the United States]] (SCOTUS) of the same legal issue, the constitutionality of banning a disparaging trademark. The USPTO appealed the decision by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit which found in December 2015 that part of the Lanham Act is unconstitutional. That case ([[Matal v. Tam]]) involved the denial of a trademark for an Asian-American rock band, "The Slants". The National Asian Pacific American Bar Association (NAPABA) filed an amicus brief supporting the constitutionality of the Lanham Act, NAPABA President Cyndie Chang stating “Racial slurs should not be recognized as commercial speech through federally-protected trademarks. “Freedom of speech does not require that the government allow racially derogatory terms to be trademarked so that a trademark owner can have exclusive rights to use and monetize such terms.”<ref>{{cite news| url=http://aapress.com/editorial/napaba-disagrees-with-band-in-trademark-case/| title=NAPABA disagrees with band in trademark case| date=January 21, 2017| publisher=Asian American Press}}</ref> On June 19, 2017 the court ruled unanimously in favor of Tam, the majority opinion stating "The disparagement clause violates the First Amendment’s Free Speech Clause. Contrary to the Government’s contention, trademarks are private, not government speech."<ref>{{cite web|title=15-1293 Martal V. Tam|url=https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/16pdf/15-1293_1o13.pdf|accessdate=19 June 2017}}</ref> Both the Native American petitioners and the Justice Department have withdrawn from any further litigation now that the Supreme Court has rendered the legal issue moot.<ref>{{cite news|title=Washington Redskins win trademark fight over the team’s name|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/public-safety/2017/06/29/a26f52f0-5cf6-11e7-9fc6-c7ef4bc58d13_story.html|accessdate=30 June 2017| author1=Ian Shapira| author2=Ann E. Marimow| date=June 29, 2017| newspaper=The Washington Post}}</ref>
==See also== *"[[Go Fund Yourself]]", a 2014 ''[[South Park]]'' episode referencing the dispute
